content_blocks.title: About me
content_blocks.description: This page is mainly about my career experience and expectations.

content_blocks.content_html:
I am lucky to experience or have experienced different roles in my life. The following are the most typical ones.

Educator

When it comes to making a difference in the world, educators have been on top of the list. Two years ago, I aspired to be an educator and successfully landed a part-time teaching job at Northern Arizona University (NAU) and later a full-time position at Academy of Math and Science (AMS), a K-8 school in Phoenix, Arizona, United States. 

As an educator, it has always been my passion and determination to enlighten students and help them capture the “aha” moments. They also reminded me of capturing my sparkles and pushing my limits higher. These years, I have gradually solidified my interests and passion in the cocktail of linguistics & computer science, especially data science and natural language processing (NLP).

Language Enthusiast & Translator

I found myself passionate in languages at a young age, when I quickly picked up dialects that my family members were speaking - Xiang Chinese (also with different variations: Urban Changsha, Ningxiang, and Xiangtan) and Cantonese. In middle school, I started to expose myself to a second foreign language (French) and I started to learn it systematically when I was in college. I am learning Spanish and Finnish at the moment. By obtaining my first master's degree in Translation at the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), I also honed my skills in translation and interpretation. I am happy to have worked for Arizona State University (ASU), National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and PAC-12 with Arizona State University, and for French Institute with Embassy of France in China, as well as other organizations when I was working part-time as a translator and interpreter.

Linguist & Programmer

My never-ending interests in computers date back to my childhood, when my parents opened a new Pentium III computer right from the box. At the age of 6, excited and surprised, I started my journey to fiddle around with my new toy. I started coding in Python 2.x when I was in high school. At Hunan University (HNU) in China, I was working part-time as a Full Stack Developer in 1000 Internet and Culture Studio (link is in Chinese), a student-operated studio. In Spring 2021 at NAU, I was fortunate to take Programming for Text Analysis with Dr. Egbert, and it reignited my passion for integrating computer science and linguistics. Presently, as a Foreign Language Teacher in Phoenix, I always strive to make a tight integration of my current job and future envisions. Elected as the Director of the AMS South Mountain Robotics and Programming Club, I am actively playing a leading role in the Club started in January 2022. 

Propelled by ambition and desire to become a computational linguist, I also keep sharpening my coding and data analysis skills (Python & R) on DataCamp and Udemy. Meanwhile, I have also taught myself algorithms and statistical methods regarding NLP and computational linguistics. I am also glad I have been, once again, an active GitHub stargazer and user since the end of 2021.

For more information, please check out my CV. If you have any questions about me or my research/work, please feel free to connect with me, by clicking any button (social media) below.

content_blocks.title: Hey there, I am Rui Hu
content_blocks.description_html:
Also known as Sherman, Rui (pronounced as ROO-ee in English), or 胡睿 (Hú Ruì in Chinese).

 

I aspire to be an Applied and Computational Linguist and Data Scientist.

 

Currently, based in Phoenix Metropolitan Area, Arizona, United States, I work as a K-8 educator in South Phoenix. In my spare time, I enjoy sharpening my programming and data analysis skills. I am also fond of traveling and taking photos. Swimming is my favorite sport although I am probably in the snack aisle.

content_blocks.content_html:
Research Interests

My main research interests are in applying both linguistic and computational approaches to investigate the properties (such as meaning) of natural language in use through corpora. Topics of interests include discourse and sentiment analysis, natural language processing/understanding, phonetics, syntax-semantics interface, as well as language and speech. These interests have driven me toward the following directions: 

  • Discourse and Sentiment Analysis: How can we effectively analyze discourse in natural languages with various parsing frameworks? 
  • Natural Language Processing/Understanding: How effectively do the models handle human languages? What machine models inform linguists about human languages?

content_blocks.title: Research
content_blocks.description: Currently, this page only highlights the major research projects that I have completed. Other than the following projects, I have completed "smaller" projects located in the Miscellaneous page.

content_blocks.content_html:
Building a Twitter Scraper & a Prototype Dictionary-based Sentiment Analyzer

  • Northern Arizona University, individual work, 2021
  • Course: Programming for Text Analysis
    • Created several Python programs and collected Tweets (N = 3,200) from Twitter and built a corpus of Tweets;  
    • Created a prototype dictionary-based sentiment analyzer and created a scoring system of the sentiment;
    • Compared the scoring by the prototype dictionary-based sentiment analyzer against the one by pre-trained machine learning sentiment analyzer;
    • Discussed the implications for sentiment dictionary building and applied linguistics research

Second Language (L2) English Speaker Analysis

  • Northern Arizona University, individual work, 2020
  • Course: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
    • Interviewed a non-native English speaker (N = 1) and collected the speech data by recording the interview with a semi-structured protocol;
    • Comprehensively analyzed the speech data at the levels of phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics/lexicon;
    • From the perspective of L1-L2 transfer, analyzed the features of the speaker's speech and summarized the features that were rooted in the speaker's first language (L1) and the ones that were independent of the speaker's L1;
    • Provided a summary of potential instructional priorities on improving the speaker's English speaking

Characteristics of a Reading Comprehension Assessment: Measures of Validity and Reliability

  • Northern Arizona University, collaborative work, 2020
  • Course: Assessment for Second Language Skills
    • Developed a test to measure native and non-native English speakers' reading comprehension in the context of academic English (N = 26);
    • Investigated the validity and reliability of the test;
    • Examined the test results by referring to descriptive statistics (mean, mode, midpoint, maximum, and minimum) and data distribution (standard deviation, skewness, and kurtosis of the curve);
    • Discussed whether there was a statistically significant difference between the test results of native speakers and those of non-native speakers

Native and Non-native Speakers' Perception of American English Dialects

  • Northern Arizona University, collaborative work, 2020
  • Course: Sociolinguistics
    • Discussed to what extent both native and non-native speakers perceive different dialects in the US regarding correctness and pleasantness (N = 54)
    • Performed independent t-tests of correctness and pleasantness scores to examine whether there was a statistically significant difference between native and non-native speakers' ratings in terms of correctness and pleasantness
    • Discussed the implications for language teaching and teacher training
